docs.snippet: Charlie Chaplin's silence, it seems, may run deeper than that he enacted on the silver screen, according to documents released on Friday by the British spy agency MI5, Reuters reported.     The documents, based on an investigation begun in 1952 in...
docs.lead_paragraph: Charlie Chaplin's silence, it seems, may run deeper than that he enacted on the silver screen, according to documents released on Friday by the British spy agency MI5, Reuters reported. The documents, based on an investigation begun in 1952 in response to F.B.I. claims that Chaplin was a dangerous Communist sympathizer, could find no record of his birth, nor any evidence to support the notion, floated by the F.B.I, that he was using an alias and was really named Israel Thornstein.
docs.abstract: British intelligence agency MI5 releases documents from a 1952 investigation of Charlie Chaplin revealing that the agency could find no record of his birth nor any evidence to support the notion, floated by the FBI, that he was a dangerous Communist sympathizer who was really named Israel Thornstein. (M)

docs.snippet: Though his career stretches from rockers (''Sid and Nancy'') to monsters (''Dracula''), with lauded turns in ''The Dark Knight'' and the ''Harry Potter'' series, Gary Oldman has just this year received his very first Oscar nomination, for best act...
docs.lead_paragraph: Though his career stretches from rockers (''Sid and Nancy'') to monsters (''Dracula''), with lauded turns in ''The Dark Knight'' and the ''Harry Potter'' series, Gary Oldman has just this year received his very first Oscar nomination, for best actor, for his portrayal of the dour cold war spook George Smiley in Tomas Alfredson's remake of John le Carre's ''Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy.'' The original British mini-series, made in 1979, starred Alec Guinness as Smiley. Mr. Oldman, who can do a fair Guinness-as-Obi-Wan Kenobi impression, didn't rewatch it, for fear of contaminating his performance. (Mr. Oldman is more than decent at impressions; when he jams on Beatles covers with friends, he's always Paul.) Over tea at an Upper East Side hotel, he recently spoke with the Bagger about the turns in his career (he hopes to direct again soon and is working on a script set in the 19th century) and why he was so comfortable playing Smiley on screen. ''He spent a great deal of it sitting down,'' Mr. Oldman said. ''I got quite used to it. I don't know whether I could ever go back to acting standing up.''
docs.abstract: Actor Gary Oldman, who has received his first Oscar nomination for the role of George Smiley in Tomas Alfredson movie Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy, discusses his fondness for the character, his acting career and future plans. Photo (M)4

headline.main: A Word WIth: Gary Oldman: Embracing George Smiley
